title: Think Marketing with Google: Agile, Outcomes Driven, Digital Advertising

json.text: Hi everyone.
Welcome to our presentation on the Think With Google series.
My name is Avinash.
I am the author of the books Web Analytics: An Hour a Day,
and Web Analytics 2.0, and the digital marketing evangelist
for Google.
The presentation is going to cover a topic that is very
near and dear to my heart.
Agile, outcomes-driven marketing.
We have a lot of data that we have access to
in the online world--
especially as we contrast it with the data that we have
available in the offline world--
when we do marketing campaigns on TV, radio,
magazines, et cetera.
All of those channels are really wonderful, but one
place where digital certainly has an edge is in its ability
to be an immensely measurable and accountable medium.
And in this webinar, I'm going to focus on how to transform
companies by focusing on, not the random set of data that
all of us have available to--
your clicks and page views, and visits, and impressions
and bombard those on our organizations--
but to actually really, really, really
focus on what matters.
In this presentation, I'm going to focus primarily on
search marketing and primarily on Google search marketing.
But there is nothing in this webinar that is unique to the
activities that you are able to do in Google.
So the principles that you are going to learn about
outcomes-driven marketing you'll be able to apply across
the board, regardless of the channel you're using--
YouTube, Bing, and Yahoo, and other channels in the world--
or the strategies that you are executing.
Whether it's affiliate or email or paid search or
anything else that you might be doing.
I was recently in Norway to give a keynote and this is one
of the searches that I did.
And loosely it translates into cheap flights to New York.
And this is, of course, a key part of every company's search
marketing, which is to have results show up on Google.
Here's a bunch of wonderful, organic search ads surrounded
by some very good paid search ads from travel companies,
from airlines, from agents, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera.
And today when we measure success of these kinds of
campaigns, I believe that we are not holding our campaigns
and ourselves as accountable as we possibly could be.
So in this webinar I'm going to break the focus on analysis
into three different pieces.
And the first is a toddler phase, and I observe that the
tons of companies that I work with around the world are
actually in this phase.
And then I'm going to move on to a teenage phase.
If you are doing this to any great degree of awesomeness,
what does that look like?
And then I'm going to end with what I believe the creme de la
creme, the most amazing of amazing companies are doing
out there when it comes to holding their marketing
successful and accountable in terms of delivering value to
the businesses.
So with that, let's get going and look at the first phase,
which is the toddler phase.
And typically, in this phase, one of the misunderstandings
that a lot of people have is that you have to spend a lot
of time and energy in tagging your site, or campaigns, or
having to beg your IT team or other people to do all kinds
of things in order to collect data to make your campaigns
accountable.
When the reality is, actually if you do nothing--
literally nothing--
in terms of efforts on your end, all you do is simply buy
search ads, you actually have access to
tons and tons of data.
This is something that not a lot of people understand.
And then what would happen is-- let's say you buy search
ads using Google Adwords--
and as soon as you have your campaigns running, boom,
instantly, you can actually have access to data.
Before I go on, I must point out that all of the data that
you will see in this presentation is made up.
And the clients are all made up.
And this does not reflect anybody or any clients' data
in any way, shape, or form.
I just created some examples to make the points that I want
to in this presentation.
So in this case, given our European theme, I just made up
an example of a company called Renault.
And in this case it's in the auto industry.
And you can see that they're buying search ads.
So as soon as they log in to Google AdWords they'll, of
course, instantly be able to recognize the first column
that you see here, which is the max CPC.
And these are the amounts that the company has decided
they're willing to pay for their search advertising.
But of course this is not the only data you have.
Without doing any additional things you'll be able to
understand which campaigns are running and which are not.
And you'll be able to get data about the primitive
performance of your campaigns.
So in this case we can understand the impressions for
the ads that are showing up when we are running our
advertising.
It'll show the clicks that those ads are receiving, and
we get the all-important metric of click-through rate.
So just think about even just this little piece of data, and
how it is already far superior to what you might be able to
get from say, TV or radio or magazines or other places.
Because here you understand exactly how many times the
magazine was opened and your ad was seen.
You can understand how many times people interacted with
the ad and actually took an action based on that.
In this case we've got click-through rate.
But of course that's not the only piece of the puzzle that
is instantly available to you.
You also have access to other valuable sources of
information, which is, how is your money being used to a
very granular level?
So in this case, we can see our average CPCs available in
this column.
We can see the cost that we have expended in each of these
campaigns so far and we're able to see the position in
which our ads are showing up on google.com.
So this data is available to you almost instantly.
So you can begin your analysis by understanding what is the
cost of your campaigns, given the maximum amount you're
willing to pay.
And you can look for trends in this data already and see if
any of them are really high or really low and how you might
be able to use that information to
optimize these campaigns.
But of course there are other things that you're doing when
you're buying search ads on Google.
Here in this case you can see a broad-matched query for the
word Renault And you're able to quickly see how many
impressions and clicks it is getting, and of course, focus
on the click-through rate metrics in this case.
Or in another case you can see the exact match ads that
you're running.
And these ads might be different, with different copy
and calls to actions, et cetera, et cetera.
And you're able to see when or how many times are those ads
showing up.
In this case, 55,000 compared to half a million for the
earlier case.
But then you are also able to compare and contrast the
meaningful metric than just click-through rate.
In this case 6.28% compared to 2.17%.
And while broad match and exact match target completely
different types of audiences--
in one case we're trying to get in front of people who are
higher up in the funnel and are searching more generically
and haven't made up their mind, and in the latter cases,
people who are looking for more specific things.
It is important to use this kind of data in order to go
out and optimize your campaigns.
But of course that's not the only thing that's
available to you.
You're actually able to see the cost per click for each of
these campaigns--
$2.29 versus is $1.24--
and use that to make better decisions.
And especially in contrast to the amount of impressions and
clicks you're able to get, the number of people in front of
whom you're able to show up.
And all of this data is available to you
without doing much work.
You can even deep dive into the data and say, well, we're
also buying the misspelling of the word Renault.
And what is the impact of that campaign?
Should we be spending $3,000 on this particular campaign,
when we are receiving the 0.1% click-through rate, and at an
average CPC of $3.57?
And this data is very useful for you to then go back and
say, well, is this a good thing, or is this not a great
thing for us to do?
So one of the great things to realize is that even without
doing a lot of work, you can anchor, from day one, the
analysis of actual cost of your keywords that you're
purchasing on Google.
But of course that's not just the only thing that's
available to you.
You can also do other more interesting analyses.
Like in this case, I'm looking at my campaigns, collections
of keywords that I have structured into logical
buckets, if you will.
And in this case, again, you've still got the cost as
an anchor to do analysis.
But you also can focus on other more interesting things.
So in this case, for this particular campaign, the cost
is $13,000 as an average CPC of $4.21 and 0.14%
click-through rate.
And in the another case you can contrast it with this
other campaign, where you have a significantly higher
click-through rate and a lower CPC.
And as a resulting lower cost you can try and dive deeper
and understand how can you improve the campaign in purple
so that it looks more and more like the campaign in green.
And you can gain higher performance in terms of the
cost to your company that you are able to get.
So this is analysis that you can do almost day one, real
time, quickly begin optimizing your campaigns.
And while that is actually wonderful, under no scenario
would we say that that is optimal or that's where you
should stop, as a matter of fact.
In fact.
The thing that I believe beyond anything else is that
it is really, really important to move beyond the cost of
doing our marketing campaigns.
That's what so much of our marketing seems
to be focused on.
I could spend x amount, $2 million and buy 300 million
eyeballs on TV. Well, that's just all cost game, right?
And it's just an impression game.
I believe in managing to outcomes.
And that's what webinar is going to be about.
This presentation focuses on really, really amazing ways in
which you can use outcomes to optimize your marketing.
And one of the best ways in which you can do outcomes
analysis for your AdWords campaigns
with very little effort--
very little effort--
is to use the AdWords Conversion Tracking feature.
This is a really great feature because, with very little pain
involved of simply tagging one page, you can get some amazing
amount of analysis and accountability for your search
marketing campaigns.
Before I show you how to do that, let me actually show you
how the data looks like, because this is the part that
I am really excited about.
So in this case, I've got a bunch of campaigns that I'm
running, looks like for a health care business that I
have. One of the things you can get, of course, without
thinking is all of the cost stuff, impressions,
click-through rate, CPCs, cost. And this is great.
So we've already covered how on day one in real time you
can start optimizing campaigns based on this.
The great thing about using the Conversion Optimizer is
that it actually tells you how many people accomplished an
outcome on your website when they came to your
site on this campaign.
So you begin to see very, very quickly, not just that you're
spending money, but that you're getting
something for it.
And so you can start focusing on metrics that have a
business impact like conversion rate.
And more than that, you can get this metric that is so
beautiful, a cost per conversion.
Not just a cost per click, which is where we were
focusing on before, cost per conversion.
Certainly a metric that is of much more immense value than
just looking at CPCs.
Of course, you don't have to stop here.
You can actually look at even more cooler things.
For example, in the past you would have focused on just the
average cost per click and highs and lows in there.
So in this case, the seniors-only campaign has a
CPC a $4.21, and the competitive-offers' campaign
has a $0.75 average CPC.
And you would probably make one set of decisions.
And now you can actually rather focus on the things
that matter.
The cost per outcome for your business
conversion, in this case.
And you can start to see that as a campaign you're running
in New York that is a cost per conversion of $1,378, and
there's another one that you're running for California
that's $95 only.
And so you could begin to start to say, hey, hey, hey,
hey, what's going on here?
And what can we do in order to have a much more balanced
portfolio of cost per conversion for our website?
And the great thing is you can do this analysis at any level
in AdWords.
As you know that there are text ads that you can--
you serve in AdWords, and they're part of campaigns,
which are part of ad groups.
And I have hidden those in this case just to leave the
imagination sort of run free.
We can actually look at individual text ads that
you're running, and you can begin to see the metrics that
matter the most for those campaigns.
So very quickly you're able to focus on the thing that is
important, the cost per conversion, the cost for
acquiring the customer for your business, and not just on
the cost that you're spending on the campaigns, and do some
really great analysis.
And if you really want to do this, it's
actually amazingly easy.
I've created a customized short URL for you.
If you're logged into AdWords already just click on a
zqi.me/ctracking, for conversion
tracking, if you will.
And when you click on that URL, you'll go directly into
AdWords, and you'll be able to start creating--
you'll start the process of engaging
the conversion tracking.
So you'll get a screen that looks something like this.
And in this scenario you'll just be able to click on New
Conversion.
And when I click on New Conversion, I get this view.
And in this case the first thing I will do is, I will
assign a name to the action that I'm are inputting.
In this case, Orders.
And then secondarily, I will click on Tracking Purpose.
And I will set Purchase or Sales-- you could pick a
sign-up lead, view of a key page, or any other kind of
conversion.
To keep things simple, I'm going to say, Orders.
And then I click on the Save and Continue button.
So far so good.
And I arrive on this screen, where I can actually get the
code that I need.
I can customize some other things if I
need to on this page.
The security, the markup language, just a few seconds
worth of work.
I can actually optionally input an average revenue for
my conversion.
You don't have to do this, but one best practice might be to
look at the average order size on your website and perhaps
use that as a proxy for revenue for the conversion.
Secondarily I can, say, choose the indicator settings.
I just said None in this scenario-- you could choose
whatever you want--
and I click on the button Save and Get Code, which takes me
to the next screen from which I will copy the code that I
need to put on my order
confirmation page on my website.
And let me show you what it looks like.
Let's say I am the person at Macy's responsible for doing
optimization.
I will take my conversion tracking code, and I will
implement it on the page that comes up after somebody has
completed checkout of, in this case, this Nespresso coffee
maker-- which is a wonderful coffee maker--
and the page that comes up is an order confirmation page.
All I need to do--
all I need to do-- is just put the conversion tracking page
on that one single page, and I am in business.
If I was running a B2B business, for example, Texas
Instruments, for my AdWords campaign, success would be
that people come to the website and download this
super important brochure--
the ultra low power microcontroller brochure--
for medical instruments.
And so what I can do is I can actually structure where I am
getting conversion tracking signal every time somebody
successfully downloads this brochure.
And I can go and optimize my AdWords campaigns there.
So whether you are a B2B or a B2C, you are able to use this
type of functionality in order to do analysis.
So there you go, my goals conversion tracking is all set
up, ready to go.
If you actually use Google Analytics-- in case you use
Google Analytics--
you actually also have this other really wonderful option
where you can import goals that you might have already
created in Google Analytics , and you don't have to go
through the process, the four steps,
that I just went through.
You can just go in, say yes, import the goals.
AdWords will automatically bring them into Google
Analytics, and you'll be able to see them here.
You can check the ones you want and you just say Import.
You just click on this button, and boom, you're in business.
So in this case, I have created goals for all of these
things in Google Analytics, and now I can bring them into
AdWords and use them to optimize my campaigns.
And again, to reiterate, what we're trying to do here, is
we're trying to make sure that we use conversion tracking and
conversions in order to optimize our campaign, so that
we focus on the things that are really important.
In this case, where is the cost per
conversions the lowest?
Where are we getting the highest number of conversions.
And then go back and touch our campaigns, rather than simply
focusing on clicks and impressions.
We're in the toddler stage, right now, of analytics and
optimization.
And this would be sort of the baby state.
So we're moving away from a tiny baby, which are the
things you would do in the first few hours that you did
AdWords, to actually doing things that will really help
you improve your campaigns.
But there are two other really amazing benefits that you can
get if you use conversion tracking from AdWords.
The first one is, that you're actually able to let AdWords
optimize your campaigns and set up them perfectly by using
the Conversion Optimizer product.
So in this case, for example, I can go in and say, well, I
don't want to fiddle with all of the settings and buttons
and whatnot for my campaign, I'm going to just say that I
want a max CPA, the cost of acquisition for every
conversion I have to be $14.60 in this case.
I could type in $2.00, whatever I would like it to
be, and AdWords will automatically--
automatically--
manage all the bids.
So then you don't have to worry about twiddling the
buttons and et cetera, et cetera, if you don't want to.
You definitely have the option of doing that, but you don't
have to in this case.
Everything will be done in order to make sure that the
outcomes delivered to you from AdWords are at the price that
you have selected yourself.
And you're able to change, of course, these
things anytime you want.
A second benefit of using Conversion Optimizer is
actually this idea of
multi-session purchase behaviors.
Let me quickly tell you what it is.
On many. many websites people might not actually purchase on
the first visit.
They might come and say, I want to search for cruise
lines, I'm going to a bunch of sites, I end up at Travelocity
or some other website.
And then I might forget about it.
And then a few days later somebody will nag me and say,
what happened, what happened to our vacation?
And I might go back, search again, and then end up on
Travelocity again, and maybe end up making a
purchase, et cetera.
So this multi-purchase behavior is not reported in an
optimal way in many analytics tools.
But if you have Conversion Optimizer implemented on your
website, you have access to a feature called Search Funnels.
And the great thing about Search Funnels is that you're
able to get of really cool set of data-- automatically, by
the way, you don't have to do anything
extra to get this data--
and you're able to see some interesting things
within your data set.
For example, for your keywords, not only are you
able to say, how many conversions happened where a
particular keyword happened to be the last click leading up
to a conversion--
in this case, the word "store" led to 325--
but you are also able to analyze and understand that
the word "store" was instrumental in 41 additional
conversions where the click didn't happen exactly at the
conversion point, but it happened
earlier in the funnel.
So it actually introduced people to your franchise who
later converted on different keywords, et cetera.
So now you have a much better idea of how various keywords
are performing, both in terms of the last click conversions,
but also where they're assisting in the other
conversions.
Additionally what you can also understand is the path or the
length of things that are happening in terms of
conversion points.
How many times, is it the first time, second time et
cetera, et cetera.
So you can get this kind of reporting very wonderfully as
well if you use AdWords Conversion Optimizer.
Now, this kind of analysis and this kind of actions also
works regardless of the types of ads that you're running.
So for example, one of the things that I'm really excited
about, are mobile ads.
I mean mobile is just a fantastic way of targeting
people in a very, very perfect way.
I tend to think of it as perhaps the holy grail of
showing the right ad to the right person at the right
time, because there's so much contextual data available that
makes it even more valuable to target the
right ads to the people.
In this case I have run a query for car rental, and I
see a couple ads very quickly for companies that
are close to me.
In this case it actually shows me it is 2.2 miles away.
And I can click and go to their website.
I can click and call, which is amazing.
I can click on this plus sign and open a map and know
exactly where it is, and perhaps drive there to pick up
another car.
Things like that.
And when you do mobile advertising, one of the the
cool things is, it comes built in with the kind of data you
need to do really good analysis.
So for example, you'll get this kind of data, from a
Vincent Rocks campaign.
I can actually see impressions, clicks, and CPCs,
which is my normal stuff.
But if I have conversion tracking--
this is so awesome--
I can also get the outcomes for those kinds of campaigns.
So in this case, as an example, I'm able to
understand that there were 23 clicks for my Vincent Rocks
campaigns, and there were two conversions happen in my
website at this cost. And it's like, wow, that's amazing.
My average cost per acquisition is actually $280,
and I'm actually only doing for $125 in
mobile, that is fabulous.
But the other thing that you can also do is, very, very
quickly move beyond just the conversion data.
Mobile is all about calling.
And so in this case, you're actually able to get data for
the mobile call activity that happens as a result of this
AdWords ad.
And all you have to do-- this is so simple.
It requires no amount of extra coding effort on your end,
everything just happens magically inside AdWords.
All you have to do is follow this four-step process that
you see on the screen.
Just pick a phone number where you want the
phone call to go to.
Pick a call format.
Choose--
I recommend this-- choose to have call metrics available to
you for your clicks.
And at the end of it when you hit Save, boom, you're going
to get the data that you really, really want.
So in this case, for my--
again, I seem to be in the insurance business--
but in the case of my campaigns, I'm able to see the
number of missed calls, the number of received calls and
the average call duration.
And the nice thing is, I already know that if a lead
stays on the phone for more than three minutes, it is
highly likely--
using my traditional insights, I know that, that data I know
that-- that they would lead to conversions.
In this case, my mobile click to call campaigns are
performing spectacularly.
Even if I am getting only 13,000 calls, these calls are
actually highly converting and actually causing a lot of
value to my business.
And all you need to do in order to see this data is--
I promise you don't have to tag, et cetera--
you just go and check on your call metrics radio icon, and
boom, you're going to have all this data available to you.
So you can see in this scenario, by combining doing
zero amounts of work and combining doing a little bit
of work by tagging only one single page on your website,
the conversion page, you're able to get some really
fabulous analysis in order to measure the outcomes that you
are getting from your campaigns.
Whether they're your mobile branding campaigns--
in this case, I just type car, and boom,
there's an ad for Geico.
And there's no other ads, right?
The bottom is covered by the screen, the top is covered by
my Google Instant, so what a great branding opportunity
here for any company.
So I can measure if this is a good way in order for me to
spend my marketing dollars and measure success.
So the bottom line for the toddler stage is this.
I'm going to simplify it by making a simple table.
I've got two campaigns that I'm running.
I call one the Avinash campaign, I call the other one
a Lauren campaign.
And in this case when I begin my AdWords work, I will focus
on the primitive metrics.
I'll focus on the impressions, and clicks, and click-through
rates, and average CPCs.
And these are great, right, they are perfect, available to
you with zero pain, instantly.
And the other thing that I will do after a few days is I
will use the AdWords conversion tracking feature in
order to start to measure the real impact on my business.
I will measure the number of conversions I get from each
campaign, and I will measure the conversion rate from each
of these campaigns.
And notice that if I had made a decision here, that might be
a different decision based on click-through
rate 5 and 10 here.
And then I would have made on conversion rate 20 and 5 here.
So you can begin to see a very different
picture of your campaigns.
And finally, I can actually begin to measure the metrics
that are very important for any marketing campaign, the
CPA, the Cost Per Acquisition.
$5 for the Avinash campaign and $20
for the Lauren campaign.
And that really, really helps me measure success with very
little effort involved at my end, except having to tag one
single page on my website and just going into AdWords and
getting all of my data.
So that is a fabulous introduction
to the toddler phase.
When you're just getting started what are the kinds of
metrics you should focus on, or the kinds of
things you can do.
But we can, of course, kick it up a notch, several notches.
And that takes us into our rockin' teen phase.
And I love this phase because you're introduced to a lot of
new, amazing things, and well, we're going to
have some fun, watch.
So we've already covered measuring cost per click.
Yay, congratulations to us.
We've already measured cost per conversion.
Yay, yay, even better things to do.
But what about the things that our bosses love.
Revenue and the behavior of consumers in the site.
Well, we haven't done that, and that's exactly what we're
going to do in the toddler phase of our evolution.
So there are only two simple steps that are required in
order to accomplish everything I'm going to
tell you in this phase.
The very first one is you would have to tag your website
with a web analytics tool.
So this is my blog, Occam's Razor, and in this case I've
already tagged it, so let me just show you how that works.
On every single page on my blog, if you do a view source,
you'll easily and quickly see the web
analytics tool I am using.
I've got eight different ones, and this is the screen shot of
the Google Analytics tool that I'm using.
And you can see my tag, and you can see that it's all
implemented.
So the very first step is if you want to do this kind of
rockin' teen analysis, you're going to have to tag your
entire website with some kind of web analytics tool.
It could be Omniture, Webtrends, Coremetrics, Yahoo
Analytics, something from Baidu, doesn't really matter.
You've got to have your website tagged completely and
properly using a web analytics tool.
If you're using Google Analytics, there is a
secondary step that you can apply in this scenario, which
is, to actually tie your AdWords account to your Google
Analytics account.
And what this does is gives you two incredible benefits.
First, is that you don't have to tag all your campaigns.
This is such a painful amount of work you have to do, and
you have to do so consistently, with proper
metadata, and proper processes, and make sure that
nobody is running campaigns without the proper, absolute
correct tags that are required.
Because no tags, no data, bottom line, right?
No campaign tags, you have no idea how your AdWords
campaigns are doing.
So that's one great benefit you can get if you tie those
two accounts.
The second benefit you get is that all of your AdWords data
will automatically be imported into Google Analytics, and
you'll be able to do some really in-depth analysis of
your AdWords campaigns.
This importation feature is also available in other web
analytics tool, and they have a different process of doing
it, but with Google Analytics you don't have
to worry about it.
All your campaigns are autotagged, all your data is
auto-imported.
If you're really interested in tagging your Google Analytics
account with your AdWords account, simply go to this
short URL, and you'll have a user guide, step by step,
exactly how to do it.
zqi.me/gaadw, and you'll be in business.
The great thing is as soon as you do this and you log in to
Google Analytics, you'll be able to get
amazing amounts of data.
So in this case I just logged into my website, and I click
on this little button here that says Advanced Segments
And it opens up all these segments that
I've already created.
And I click on the default Advance Segment
of Paid Search Traffic.
You don't have to create this, it's already
there in Google Analytics.
And as soon as you click on that button and say OK, there
we go, boom, all your paid-search data is there.
You know exactly how much traffic you're getting.
You get great metrics like bounce rate and new visits,
and time inside and on and on and on and on.
So you get amazing amounts of data almost right away.
Now, the thing is I promised you that we're going to focus
on outcomes, so we're going to focus on outcomes.
And we're not going to focus on anything else.
And the way we're going to do this is, we're going to be a
little subversive, and we're going to ignore all the
standard reports.
And we're going to use a custom report I have
especially created to analyze my paid-search campaigns.
And so I go away from having to troll through 20, 30
